metadata.title: Interactions of Pseudorabies Virus With Swine Alveolar Macrophages: Effects of Virus Infection on Cell Functions

abstract.text: In order to assess the effect of pseudorabies virus (PRV) Infection on the function of swine alveolar macrophages (AM), lung lavage cells were cultured, infected with one of six strains of PRy, and various activities were measured. Activity measurement Included viability, phagocytosis of yeast, phagosome-lysosome fusion, phagocytosis of opsonized particles, and superoxide release. AM were infected with 5 x 10 PFU/cell, and the comparative assessment of functions was performed at 18-20 h postinfection. Cell viability in PRy-infected cultures ranged from 79 to 94% of the viability in noninfected cultures. Phagocytosis of yeast was significantly reduced only In the AM cultures infected with the strain S-62. Phagosome-iysosome fusion was depressed in cultures Infected with the strains S-62, 4892, 3816, and BUK. The phagocytosls of opsonized sheep red blood cells showed significant differences between noninfected and PRyinfected cultures in all cases except cultures Infected with the strain PRy-C. The 02 release after stimulation with opsonlzed zymosan was significantly reduced in all the PR V-infected cultures. The effect of PRV infection on AM functions that are related to the bacterial activity of such cells suggests that PRV-induced AM dysfunction might have a role in the increased susceptibility of PRV-infected pigs to bacterial pneumonia.

Each test was evaluated in triplicate.

The results of the experiments presented here leave no doubt that PRY infection leads to AM dysfunction even before cell death that is due to virus replication. Project No. 16200.
